descript.abstract: The Component Table describes each of the individual soil landscapes which comprise the polygon (i.e. the components of the polygon). Note that components apply to only to the land and wetland portion of the polygon.
descript.purpose: The Alberta Component Table (CMP) forms part of the Soil Information Database for the province of Alberta (ABSID)
descript.supplinf: Additional information can be found on the Canadian Soil Information System (CanSIS) website at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/dss/v3/index.html

citeinfo.origin: Government of Canada / Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC)
citeinfo.title: Alberta Soil Name Table (SNT)

crossref.assndesc: The Soil Name Table (SNT) describes the general chemical and physical properties for each soil found in a geographic region. The CMP is connected to the SNT through the common SOIL_ID field via a many-to-one (N:1) relationship.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

cntorgp.cntorg: Government of Canada/Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC)

attr.attrdef: Polygon Identifier: This polygon identifier is used to join attribute datasets (such as the CMP) to the Polygon Attribute Table (PAT). More than one polygon in the spatial dataset may share the same POLY_ID. This field is a concatenation of the survey identifier (6 characters) and a 6 character feature identifier.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/poly_id.html

attr.attrdef: Component Number: A number that uniquely identifies a constituent part of a polygon.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/cmp.html

attr.attrdef: Percent of polygon occupied by the component: Percentage of the land area of the polygon which is occupied by the component.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/percent.html

attr.attrdef:
Slope Steepness: Predominant slope of the landscape.
Slope (%) Approximate degrees Terminology
0 - 0.5 0 Level
0.5 - 2 0.3 - 1.1 Nearly level
2 - 5 1.1 - 3 Very gentle slopes
5 - 9 3 - 5 Gentle slopes
9 - 15 5 - 8.5 Moderate slopes
15 - 30 8.5 - 16.5 Strong slopes
30 - 45 16.5 - 24 Very strong slopes
45 - 70 24 - 35 Extreme slopes
70 - 100 35 - 45 Steep slopes
> 100 > 45 Very steep slopes
-9 n/a Unknown or not applicable
While this is a numeric field, the values will often be the mid point of the traditional slope classes described in the table above.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/slope_p.html

attr.attrdef: Slope Length: Average slope length from crest to depression.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/slope_len.html

attr.attrdef: Surface Stoniness Class: Rock fragments on the surface of a soil or those protruding above ground have important effects on soil use and management. The limitations they impose are related to their number, size, and spacing at the surface. The terminology that follows is further defined in the CanSIS Manual for Describing Soils in the Field.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/stoniness.html

edom.edomvd: Nonstony: No stones or too few are present to interfere with cultivation (<0.01% of surface, stones more than 25 m apart).
Slightly stony: Some stones are present that hinder cultivation slightly or not at all (0.01-0.1% of surface, stones 8-25 m apart).
Moderately stony: Enough stones are present to cause some interference with cultivation (0.1-3% of surface, stones 1-8m apart).
Very stony: There are sufficient stones to handicap cultivation seriously; some clearing is required (3-15% of surface, stones 0.5-1m apart).
Exceedingly stony: The stones prevent cultivation until considerable clearing is done (15-50% of surface, stones 0.1-0.5m apart).
Excessively stony: The land surface is too stony to permit cultivation; it is boulder or stone pavement (more than 50% of surface, stones less than 0.1m apart).

attr.attrdef: Province Code: A two-character province code used as part of a link to the CanSIS NAMES and LAYERS tables.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/province.html

attr.attrdef: Soil Code: Soil code used as part of the link to a representative soil in the CanSIS NAMES and LAYERs tables. The "#" symbol is used to denote non-applicable for areas where no soil name is established.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/soil_code.html

attr.attrdef: Soil Code Modifier: The modifier code is used to indicate a particular assemblage of characteristics related to a soil code. A soil modifier code is used as part of the link to a representative soil in the Soil Name and Soil Layer tables. The soil_code + modifier are unique within each Province or Territory for all soils (mineral or organic), nonsoils, and unclassified areas.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/modifier.html

attr.attrdef: Type of soil profile: Indicates the type of soil profile (agricultural or native). Used as part of the linkage key to the NAMES (SNT) and LAYERS (SLT) tables. The linkage is made to an agricultural model of each soil profile, where it is available (PROFILE = A). This “agricultural bias” is useful for agricultural interpretive modeling. True land use information should be consulted to determine the current land use in a particular soil map polygon.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/profile.html

edom.edomvd: Native soil profile: The soil is in native condition (undisturbed by agriculture).
Agricultural soil profile: The soil has been disturbed by agriculture.

attr.attrdef: Soil Name Identifier: This field is normally used to join the Soil Names Table (SNT) to other tables such as the Component Table (CMP). There is only one record in the SNT for any given SOIL_ID. This field is a concatenation of the PROVINCE + SOIL_CODE + MODIFIER + PROFILE fields.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/soil_id.html

attr.attrdef: Polygon Component Identifier: This field uniquely identifies a spatial component of the polygon within the dataset. It is a concatenation of the polygon identifier (POLY_ID) and the component identifier (CMP).
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/cmp_id.html

dataqual.logic:
Domain Consistency: Custom data error check programs have been run to check the geospatial attribute data, the Soil Names Table, Soil Layer Table and the Component Table against each other; most errors identified from this comprehensive check routine have been corrected but some may remain.
Format Consistency: The required standard fields for this geospatial attribute file, and the data recorded therein, comply with the National Soil Database structure specifications.
dataqual.complete: Some fields may contain missing values. This is expected, as the fields are part of the National Soil Database data model, and data for that field may not have been collected during some of the detailed soil surveys that were used to populate ABSID. ABSID does not cover the whole of the the province of Alberta.
